column4: is it possible to make sshd listen on multiple ports, or do i have to have multiple sshd running?
why would you want to do that?
because i want to have a special port for sshd to listen on that will be forwarded by my router
so only that particular server will respond to a ssh req on that port
it just sounds like you're doing something backwards, i guess :/
well, 8191 would be forwarded to my server by my router, and the only thing on my server listening on that port would be ssh
you can make almost all routers forward external port 8191 to internal port 22
it makes that server visible from outside the network
i realize that, but i have multiple servers with sshd running, i want it to forward external requests to a specific server
port forwarding has to point to a specific IP inside the firewall
i realize that to, but there may or may not be multiple redundant routers internally
in any case, is it or is it not possible to make ssh listen on multiple ports
is that really the case with your situation?
i don't know that much, and i'm sorry for wasting your time in that case ... it just seemed like there was a better way
its not a waste, im learning about ubuntu, so i think up problems, and your questions help me to reinforce my learning
in all honesty, i could just forward requests using external/internal port switching as you said, i just wanted to know IF it is possible

i think that unless you were doing some really wild and radical changes between them, you should use something like iptables or your router's config to forward 8191 to port 22, regardless of where it happens
agreed. but look at it from an academic standpoint as far as ssh customization
